content: The "Terrorism Risk Insurance Program Reauthorization Act of 2007" includes sections on the short title, definition of act of terrorism, reauthorization of the program, annual liability cap, and enhanced reports to Congress. The definition of act of terrorism is amended to exclude actions on behalf of foreign persons or interests. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 is amended to extend the Termination Date to 2014 and include Additional Program Years up to 2014. Conforming Amendments are made to the Act. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 is amended to extend the Termination Date to 2014 and include Additional Program Years up to 2014. Conforming Amendments are made to the Act, including adjustments for future Program Years. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 is amended to extend the Termination Date to 2014 and include Additional Program Years up to 2014. Adjustments for future Program Years are made, including an Annual Liability Cap. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 is amended to adjust provisions related to insured losses and insurer payments. Insurers are not required to make payments exceeding their deductible. Additionally, notice requirements to Congress are updated. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 is amended to adjust provisions related to insured losses and insurer payments, including new notice requirements to Congress and regulations for pro rata payments. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 is amended to include regulations for determining pro rata share of insured losses exceeding $100 billion, with a report to Congress required within 120 days of enactment. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 is amended to require insurers to disclose the $100 billion cap to policyholders for policies issued after 2007. Surcharges are also adjusted to 133 percent of mandatory recoupment. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 is amended to require insurers to disclose the $100 billion cap to policyholders for policies issued after 2007. Surcharges are adjusted to 133 percent of mandatory recoupment, with timing specified by the Secretary. The Secretary shall collect required premiums for acts of terrorism occurring before December 31, 2010 by September 30, 2012. For acts occurring between January 1 and December 31, 2011, 35 percent of premiums are due by September 30, 2012, with the remainder by September 30, 2017. For acts after January 1, 2012, all premiums must be collected by September 30, 2017. The Secretary will issue regulations for collecting required premiums within 180 days of enactment. An estimate of insured losses will be published within 90 days of an act of terrorism to determine mandatory recoupment. Premiums collected will be updated annually. The regulations for collecting required premiums will be updated annually, with timing requirements specified in subparagraph (D)(ii). SEC. 5. ENHANCED REPORTS TO CONGRESS. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 is amended to include a study on insurance coverage for losses from terrorist attacks involving nuclear, biological, chemical, or radiological materials. The study will assess availability, affordability, future outlook, and the capacity of insurers to manage risks. A report is required within one year. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress within one year of the Terrorism Risk Insurance Program Reauthorization Act of 2007 enactment. The report will detail findings and recommendations to enhance insurance availability and affordability for nuclear, biological, chemical, or radiological terrorist events. The Insurance Act of 2002 is amended to include a study by the Comptroller General on the availability and affordability of terrorism insurance in specific markets. The study will analyze insurance and reinsurance capacity, factors contributing to capacity constraints, and provide recommendations. The Comptroller General is required to submit a report on the study of terrorism insurance availability and affordability to the Senate and House committees. Ongoing reports on the analysis will be conducted in 2010 and 2013, with amendments to the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002.
